speaker: First Lord
text_entry: SCENE II. A banqueting-room in Timon's house.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Hautboys playing loud music. A great banquet  served in; FLAVIUS and others attending; then enter  TIMON, ALCIBIADES, Lords, Senators, and VENTIDIUS.  Then comes, dropping, after all, APEMANTUS, discontentedly, like himself

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: Most honour'd Timon,

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: It hath pleased the gods to remember my father's age,

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: And call him to long peace.

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: He is gone happy, and has left me rich:

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: Then, as in grateful virtue I am bound

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: To your free heart, I do return those talents,

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: Doubled with thanks and service, from whose help

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: I derived liberty.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: O, by no means,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Honest Ventidius; you mistake my love:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I gave it freely ever; and there's none

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Can truly say he gives, if he receives:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: If our betters play at that game, we must not dare

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To imitate them; faults that are rich are fair.

speaker: VENTIDIUS
text_entry: A noble spirit!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Nay, my lords,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: They all stand ceremoniously looking on TIMON

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Ceremony was but devised at first

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To set a gloss on faint deeds, hollow welcomes,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Recanting goodness, sorry ere 'tis shown;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: But where there is true friendship, there needs none.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Pray, sit; more welcome are ye to my fortunes

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Than my fortunes to me.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: They sit

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: My lord, we always have confess'd it.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Ho, ho, confess'd it! hang'd it, have you not?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: O, Apemantus, you are welcome.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: No;

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: You shall not make me welcome:

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: I come to have thee thrust me out of doors.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Fie, thou'rt a churl; ye've got a humour there

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Does not become a man: 'tis much to blame.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: They say, my lords, 'ira furor brevis est;' but yond

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: man is ever angry. Go, let him have a table by

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: himself, for he does neither affect company, nor is

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: he fit for't, indeed.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Let me stay at thine apperil, Timon: I come to

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: observe; I give thee warning on't.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I take no heed of thee; thou'rt an Athenian,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: therefore welcome: I myself would have no power;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: prithee, let my meat make thee silent.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: I scorn thy meat; 'twould choke me, for I should

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: ne'er flatter thee. O you gods, what a number of

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: men eat Timon, and he sees 'em not! It grieves me

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: to see so many dip their meat in one man's blood;

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: and all the madness is, he cheers them up too.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: I wonder men dare trust themselves with men:

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Methinks they should invite them without knives;

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Good for their meat, and safer for their lives.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: There's much example for't; the fellow that sits

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: next him now, parts bread with him, pledges the

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: breath of him in a divided draught, is the readiest

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: man to kill him: 't has been proved. If I were a

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: huge man, I should fear to drink at meals;

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Lest they should spy my windpipe's dangerous notes:

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Great men should drink with harness on their throats.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: My lord, in heart; and let the health go round.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Let it flow this way, my good lord.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Flow this way! A brave fellow! he keeps his tides

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: well. Those healths will make thee and thy state

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: look ill, Timon. Here's that which is too weak to

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: be a sinner, honest water, which ne'er left man i' the mire:

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: This and my food are equals; there's no odds:

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Feasts are too proud to give thanks to the gods.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Apemantus' grace.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Immortal gods, I crave no pelf;

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: I pray for no man but myself:

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Grant I may never prove so fond,

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: To trust man on his oath or bond;

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Or a harlot, for her weeping;

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Or a dog, that seems a-sleeping:

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Or a keeper with my freedom;

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Or my friends, if I should need 'em.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Amen. So fall to't:

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Rich men sin, and I eat root.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Eats and drinks

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Much good dich thy good heart, Apemantus!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Captain Alcibiades, your heart's in the field now.

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: My heart is ever at your service, my lord.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: You had rather be at a breakfast of enemies than a

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: dinner of friends.

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: So the were bleeding-new, my lord, there's no meat

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: like 'em: I could wish my best friend at such a feast.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Would all those fatterers were thine enemies then,

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: that then thou mightst kill 'em and bid me to 'em!

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Might we but have that happiness, my lord, that you

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: would once use our hearts, whereby we might express

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: some part of our zeals, we should think ourselves

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: for ever perfect.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: O, no doubt, my good friends, but the gods

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: themselves have provided that I shall have much help

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: from you: how had you been my friends else? why

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: have you that charitable title from thousands, did

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: not you chiefly belong to my heart? I have told

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: more of you to myself than you can with modesty

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: speak in your own behalf; and thus far I confirm

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: you. O you gods, think I, what need we have any

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: friends, if we should ne'er have need of 'em? they

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: were the most needless creatures living, should we

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: ne'er have use for 'em, and would most resemble

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: sweet instruments hung up in cases that keep their

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: sounds to themselves. Why, I have often wished

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: myself poorer, that I might come nearer to you. We

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: are born to do benefits: and what better or

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: properer can we can our own than the riches of our

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: friends? O, what a precious comfort 'tis, to have

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: so many, like brothers, commanding one another's

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: fortunes! O joy, e'en made away ere 't can be born!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Mine eyes cannot hold out water, methinks: to

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: forget their faults, I drink to you.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Thou weepest to make them drink, Timon.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Joy had the like conception in our eyes

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: And at that instant like a babe sprung up.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Ho, ho! I laugh to think that babe a bastard.

speaker: Third Lord
text_entry: I promise you, my lord, you moved me much.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Much!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Tucket, within

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: What means that trump?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Enter a Servant

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: How now?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Please you, my lord, there are certain

speaker: Servant
text_entry: ladies most desirous of admittance.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Ladies! what are their wills?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: There comes with them a forerunner, my lord, which

speaker: Servant
text_entry: bears that office, to signify their pleasures.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I pray, let them be admitted.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Enter Cupid

speaker: Cupid
text_entry: Hail to thee, worthy Timon, and to all

speaker: Cupid
text_entry: That of his bounties taste! The five best senses

speaker: Cupid
text_entry: Acknowledge thee their patron; and come freely

speaker: Cupid
text_entry: To gratulate thy plenteous bosom: th' ear,

speaker: Cupid
text_entry: Taste, touch and smell, pleased from thy tale rise;

speaker: Cupid
text_entry: They only now come but to feast thine eyes.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: They're welcome all; let 'em have kind admittance:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Music, make their welcome!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Exit Cupid

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: You see, my lord, how ample you're beloved.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Music. Re-enter Cupid with a mask of Ladies  as Amazons, with lutes in their hands, dancing and playing

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Hoy-day, what a sweep of vanity comes this way!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: They dance! they are mad women.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Like madness is the glory of this life.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: As this pomp shows to a little oil and root.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: We make ourselves fools, to disport ourselves;

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: And spend our flatteries, to drink those men

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Upon whose age we void it up again,

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: With poisonous spite and envy.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Who lives that's not depraved or depraves?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Who dies, that bears not one spurn to their graves

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Of their friends' gift?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: I should fear those that dance before me now

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Would one day stamp upon me: 't has been done;

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Men shut their doors against a setting sun.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: The Lords rise from table, with much adoring of  TIMON; and to show their loves, each singles out an  Amazon, and all dance, men with women, a lofty strain or two to the hautboys, and cease

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: You have done our pleasures much grace, fair ladies,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Set a fair fashion on our entertainment,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Which was not half so beautiful and kind;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: You have added worth unto 't and lustre,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And entertain'd me with mine own device;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I am to thank you for 't.

speaker: First Lady
text_entry: My lord, you take us even at the best.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: 'Faith, for the worst is filthy; and would not hold

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: taking, I doubt me.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Ladies, there is an idle banquet attends you:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Please you to dispose yourselves.

speaker: All Ladies
text_entry: Most thankfully, my lord.

speaker: All Ladies
text_entry: Exeunt Cupid and Ladies

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Flavius.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: My lord?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: The little casket bring me hither.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Yes, my lord. More jewels yet!

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: There is no crossing him in 's humour;

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Aside

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Else I should tell him,--well, i' faith I should,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: When all's spent, he 'ld be cross'd then, an he could.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: 'Tis pity bounty had not eyes behind,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: That man might ne'er be wretched for his mind.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Where be our men?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Here, my lord, in readiness.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Our horses!

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Re-enter FLAVIUS, with the casket

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: O my friends,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I have one word to say to you: look you, my good lord,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I must entreat you, honour me so much

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: As to advance this jewel; accept it and wear it,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Kind my lord.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: I am so far already in your gifts,--

speaker: All
text_entry: So are we all.

speaker: All
text_entry: Enter a Servant

speaker: Servant
text_entry: My lord, there are certain nobles of the senate

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Newly alighted, and come to visit you.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: They are fairly welcome.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: I beseech your honour,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Vouchsafe me a word; it does concern you near.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Near! why then, another time I'll hear thee:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I prithee, let's be provided to show them

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: entertainment.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: [Aside]  I scarce know how.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Enter a Second Servant

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: May it please your honour, Lord Lucius,

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: Out of his free love, hath presented to you

speaker: Second Servant
text_entry: Four milk-white horses, trapp'd in silver.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I shall accept them fairly; let the presents

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Be worthily entertain'd.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Enter a third Servant

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: How now! what news?

speaker: Third Servant
text_entry: Please you, my lord, that honourable

speaker: Third Servant
text_entry: gentleman, Lord Lucullus, entreats your company

speaker: Third Servant
text_entry: to-morrow to hunt with him, and has sent your honour

speaker: Third Servant
text_entry: two brace of greyhounds.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I'll hunt with him; and let them be received,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Not without fair reward.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: [Aside]                What will this come to?

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: He commands us to provide, and give great gifts,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: And all out of an empty coffer:

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Nor will he know his purse, or yield me this,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: To show him what a beggar his heart is,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Being of no power to make his wishes good:

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: His promises fly so beyond his state

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: That what he speaks is all in debt; he owes

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: For every word: he is so kind that he now

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Pays interest for 't; his land's put to their books.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Well, would I were gently put out of office

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Before I were forced out!

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Happier is he that has no friend to feed

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Than such that do e'en enemies exceed.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: I bleed inwardly for my lord.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: You do yourselves

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Much wrong, you bate too much of your own merits:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Here, my lord, a trifle of our love.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: With more than common thanks I will receive it.

speaker: Third Lord
text_entry: O, he's the very soul of bounty!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And now I remember, my lord, you gave

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Good words the other day of a bay courser

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I rode on: it is yours, because you liked it.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: O, I beseech you, pardon me, my lord, in that.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: You may take my word, my lord; I know, no man

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Can justly praise but what he does affect:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I weigh my friend's affection with mine own;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I'll tell you true. I'll call to you.

speaker: All Lords
text_entry: O, none so welcome.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I take all and your several visitations

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: So kind to heart, 'tis not enough to give;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Methinks, I could deal kingdoms to my friends,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And ne'er be weary. Alcibiades,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Thou art a soldier, therefore seldom rich;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: It comes in charity to thee: for all thy living

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Is 'mongst the dead, and all the lands thou hast

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Lie in a pitch'd field.

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Ay, defiled land, my lord.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: We are so virtuously bound--

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And so

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Am I to you.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: So infinitely endear'd--

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: All to you. Lights, more lights!

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: The best of happiness,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Honour and fortunes, keep with you, Lord Timon!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Ready for his friends.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Exeunt all but APEMANTUS and TIMON

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: What a coil's here!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Serving of becks and jutting-out of bums!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: I doubt whether their legs be worth the sums

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: That are given for 'em. Friendship's full of dregs:

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Methinks, false hearts should never have sound legs,

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Thus honest fools lay out their wealth on court'sies.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Now, Apemantus, if thou wert not sullen, I would be

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: good to thee.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: No, I'll nothing: for if I should be bribed too,

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: there would be none left to rail upon thee, and then

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: thou wouldst sin the faster. Thou givest so long,

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Timon, I fear me thou wilt give away thyself in

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: paper shortly: what need these feasts, pomps and

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: vain-glories?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Nay, an you begin to rail on society once, I am

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: sworn not to give regard to you. Farewell; and come

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: with better music.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Exit

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: So:

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Thou wilt not hear me now; thou shalt not then:

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: I'll lock thy heaven from thee.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: O, that men's ears should be

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: To counsel deaf, but not to flattery!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Exit
